title: How to connect Speakers to a PS4

steps.title: Buy an optical audio cable.
steps.content: Buy an optical audio cable. These cables are sometimes called "Toslink" cables. These cables have a hexagonal plastic mouth with a small jack in the middle. You can typically find them in tech departments of retail stores, or on Amazon. The PS4 Slim doesn't have an optical audio output port, so you won't be able to use this method if you have a PS4 Slim.

steps.title: Plug one end of the audio cable into your speakers' optical port.
steps.content: Plug one end of the audio cable into your speakers' optical port. The port resembles the end of the optical audio cable. You should be able to find this port on the back of the main speaker unit. If your speaker doesn't have an optical port, you can buy an optical adapter. For example, you would use an optical-to-RCA adapter to connect an optical cable to traditional red-and-white (analog stereo) speaker ports.

steps.title: Plug the other end of the cable into your PS4's optical port.
steps.content: Plug the other end of the cable into your PS4's optical port. This port is on the far-left side of the back of the PS4 while facing it.

steps.title: Turn on your PS4.
steps.content: Turn on your PS4. You should be able to hear the PS4 menu music through your speakers after a moment. If you don't hear anything, adjust your speakers' volume.

steps.title: Connect your speakers to the receiver.
steps.content: Connect your speakers to the receiver. If you haven't already done so, go ahead and make sure the speakers are connected to the proper inputs on the back of the receiver. Connect the front left and right speakers to the front left and right inputs. Connect the center speaker to the center input. Connect the rear left and right speakers to the rear left and right inputs. Finally, connect the subwoofer to the subwoofer input.

steps.title: Connect an HDMI cable to the back of the PS4.
steps.content: Connect an HDMI cable to the back of the PS4. Locate the HDMI port on the back of the PS4 and plug one end of the HDMI cable into the PS4. Alternatively, you can use an optical cable and connect to the optical port on the back of the PS4.

steps.title: Connect the other end of the cable to an "HDMI IN" port on the back of the receiver.
steps.content: Connect the other end of the cable to an "HDMI IN" port on the back of the receiver. Locate an available "HDMI IN" port on the back of the stereo or surround sound receiver and connect the other end of the HDMI cable to this port.

steps.title: Connect a second HDMI cable to the "HDMI OUT" port.
steps.content: Connect a second HDMI cable to the "HDMI OUT" port. Locate the "HDMI OUT" port on the back of your stereo or surround sound receiver. Connect one end of the HDMI cable to the HDMI out port.

steps.title: Connect the other end of the HDMI cable to your TV.
steps.content: Connect the other end of the HDMI cable to your TV. Locate an available HDMI port on the back of your TV and connect the other end of the HDMI cable to the back of your TV.

steps.title: Power on both your TV and your receiver.
steps.content: Power on both your TV and your receiver. Make sure your PS4, TV, and receiver are powered on.

steps.title: Select the proper input source on your receiver.
steps.content: Select the proper input source on your receiver. Each of the "HDMI IN" ports on the back of your receiver should be numbered. Use the remote for your surround sound or stereo receiver to select the input source that corresponds to the HDMI Input number your PS4 is connected to. You should hear sound from your PS4.

steps.title: Select the proper input source on your TV.
steps.content: Select the proper input source on your TV. Just like with your receiver, the HDMI ports on the back of your TV are also numbered. Use your TV remote to select the input source that corresponds to the HDMI port you connected your stereo receiver to. Now you should have audio and visual. If your TV has an HDMI OUT port or an Optical Out port, you can connect your TV to your stereo receiver instead. This will play whatever is on your TV through your surround sound or stereo system.

steps.title: Locate an audio out port on your TV.
steps.content: Locate an audio out port on your TV. Most televisions (but not all) have an audio-out port that allows you to connect to an external speaker or surround sound system. This may be an HDMI out, an optical cable (also known as a "Toslink" cable), or a digital cable. Connecting your TV to a speaker will allow all sound on your television (not just your PS4) to play through your speaker.

steps.title: Check the audio inputs on your speaker or stereo/surround sound receiver.
steps.content: Check the audio inputs on your speaker or stereo/surround sound receiver. Different speakers have different audio inputs. It may have multiple input choices, or it may have only a couple. Make sure your speaker takes the same audio cable as your TV's audio-out port. If it does not take the same cable, you may need to purchase an adapter.

steps.title: Connect your TV to your speaker.
steps.content: Connect your TV to your speaker. After purchasing, the correct cable, connect the cable to the audio-out port on your TV. Then connect the other end of the cable to an input on your speaker or stereo/surround sound receiver.

steps.title: Select the proper sound output on your TV.
steps.content: Select the proper sound output on your TV. In some cases, your TV may automatically detect that you are connected to a speaker or surround sound. If it does not, you may need to go into the sound settings on your TV and select the proper sound output (optical, digital, HDMI, receiver, etc).

steps.title: Buy an auxiliary cable.
steps.content: Buy an auxiliary cable. Unfortunately, Sony doesn't allow you to connect your Bluetooth speaker to your PS4 via Bluetooth, but you can use a 3.5-millimeter audio cable (also known as an auxiliary cable) to hard-wire your speaker. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Attach the speaker to your PS4 controller.
steps.content: Attach the speaker to your PS4 controller. Plug one end of the 3.5-millimeter cable into the headphone jack on the back of your PS4 controller, then plug the other end into the "Audio In" (or "Line In", or similar) jack on the back of your Bluetooth speaker.

steps.title: Turn on and sign into your PS4.
steps.content: Turn on and sign into your PS4. Press the PS button on your synced PS4 controller to turn on the PS4, then select your profile and press X .

steps.title: Open Settings.
steps.content: Open Settings. Scroll up to the menu bar, then scroll right to select the briefcase-shaped Settings icon and press X . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Scroll down and select Devices and press ✕.
steps.content: Scroll down and select Devices and press ✕ . It's about halfway down the Settings page. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Select Audio Devices and press ✕.
steps.content: Select Audio Devices and press ✕ . You'll find this option near the top of the Devices page.

steps.title: Select Output Device and press ✕.
steps.content: Select Output Device and press ✕ . This is near the top of the Audio Devices page. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Select Headset Connected to Controller and press ✕.
steps.content: Select Headset Connected to Controller and press ✕ . You'll find it on the right side of the screen. Depending on your other PS4 settings, this option may already be selected.

steps.title: Select Output to Headphones and press ✕.
steps.content: Select Output to Headphones and press ✕ . It's near the bottom of the screen. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Select All Audio and press ✕.
steps.content: Select All Audio and press ✕ . This option is on the far right side of the screen. Doing so ensures that all audio from your PS4 will be output through your controller, meaning that it should go through the connected speaker. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Turn on your speaker .
steps.content: Turn on your speaker . Press your wireless speaker's "Power" button. At this point, you should hear audio coming from the speaker when you flip through PS4 menus or the music plays. Disconnecting your speaker's cable from your controller will usually shift the audio usage back to your PS4's main speakers (e.g., the TV speakers).

steps.title: Buy an audio extractor.
steps.content: Buy an audio extractor. Audio extractors typically have two HDMI ports on opposite sides, as well as audio-out ports for either optical, 3.5mm stereo, or RCA audio cables. You can find audio extractors online or in some tech department stores. Make sure your extractor's audio output (e.g., RCA) matches your speakers' audio input. Be aware that the audio quality you will receive from an audio extractor will be inferior to the quality you would receive from plugging into your speakers.

steps.title: Buy an audio cable to connect the extractor and your speakers.
steps.content: Buy an audio cable to connect the extractor and your speakers. This cable must match your extractor's audio output and your speakers' audio input.

steps.title: Buy an additional HDMI cable.
steps.content: Buy an additional HDMI cable. The TV cable that came with your PS4 is an HDMI cable, but you'll need an extra one to connect the audio extractor to the TV.

steps.title: Plug the PS4 into the audio extractor with the first HDMI cable.
steps.content: Plug the PS4 into the audio extractor with the first HDMI cable. This cable goes in the "HDMI" slot that's on the left side of the back of the PS4 while you're facing it, and the "Audio In" HDMI port on the extractor.

steps.title: Plug the audio extractor into the TV with the second HDMI cable.
steps.content: Plug the audio extractor into the TV with the second HDMI cable. This HDMI cable connects from the audio extractor's "Audio Out" port to the TV's HDMI port.

steps.title: Plug the audio extractor into the speakers with the audio cable.
steps.content: Plug the audio extractor into the speakers with the audio cable. The audio cable will connect from the extractor's audio output to the speakers' audio input.

steps.title: Turn on your PS4.
steps.content: Turn on your PS4. You should be able to hear the PS4 menu music through your speakers after a moment. If you don't hear anything, adjust your speakers' volume.

steps.title: Buy an auxiliary cable.
steps.content: Buy an auxiliary cable. Aux cables, also known as 3.5-millimeter male-to-male cables, are audio cables with headphone jacks on each end. If you have a pair of headphones that already uses a 3.5-millimeter cable, skip this step and the next one. You can find a 3.5-millimeter male-to-male audio cable at most automotive stores, tech departments, or online shops (e.g., Amazon).

steps.title: Plug the auxiliary cable into the headphones.
steps.content: Plug the auxiliary cable into the headphones. You'll usually find this port on one of the headphone set's sides.

steps.title: Plug the other end of the cable into your controller.
steps.content: Plug the other end of the cable into your controller. The headphone port on your PS4's controller is on the back of the controller, between the two handles. If you have a pair of headphones that uses a hardwired auxiliary cable, just plug that into the controller.

steps.title: Turn on your PS4 and a connected controller.
steps.content: Turn on your PS4 and a connected controller. You can do so by pressing the PS button on the connected controller.

steps.title: Select an account and press ✕.
steps.content: Select an account and press ✕ . This will log you into the PS4.

steps.title: Scroll up.
steps.content: Scroll up. Doing so brings up the PS4 menu bar.

steps.title: Select Settings and press ✕.
steps.content: Select Settings and press ✕ . Settings is on the far right side of the menu bar.

steps.title: Scroll down to select Devices and press ✕.
steps.content: Scroll down to select Devices and press ✕ . It's near the bottom of the page.

steps.title: Select Audio Devices and press ✕.
steps.content: Select Audio Devices and press ✕ . You'll see this option near the top of the page.

steps.title: Select Output to Headphones and press ✕.
steps.content: Select Output to Headphones and press ✕ . This option is near the bottom of the page. If your aux cable isn't connected to your PS4 controller, this option will be greyed out.

steps.title: Select All Audio and press ✕.
steps.content: Select All Audio and press ✕ . This will ensure that all audio played on your PS4 comes through the headphone jack rather than through the TV's speakers.

steps.title: Press the PS button.
steps.content: Press the PS button. Now the sound from any media viewed on the PS4 will play through the cable, thereby using your headphones as an output point.
